partner-flow-story.text: Course Request. A user tries to access a partner course. These are organization-specific—not everyone can get in. Let's check the credentials!
Auth Check Gate. First gate—authentication. Is the user logged in? If not, we redirect to login.
Redirect to Login. No authentication? Redirect to login! After signing in, the user will return to try again.
Load Permissions. User is authenticated! Now we fetch their RBAC data—roles, organization memberships, and course access lists.
Organization Check. Second gate—organization membership. The user must belong to the organization that sponsors this course.
Course Access Check. Final gate—course access. Does the user have this specific course in their access list? All gates cleared means access granted!
Access Granted - Render. All checks passed! The lesson content renders. Learning begins. The multi-layer security keeps content protected.

collection-hierarchy-story.text: Firestore Root. Welcome to Firestore—our cloud database! It uses a hierarchical structure with collections, documents, and nested subcollections.
Users Collection. The users collection is our main entry point. Every registered user gets a document here, identified by their Firebase Auth UID.
Courses Collection. The courses collection stores course metadata. This is optional—mainly used for admin features and catalog displays.
User Document. Each user document stores profile info, role, and organization memberships. But that's just the start—subcollections hold the real data!
Course Progress. The courseProgress subcollection tracks progress per course. Each course the user enrolls in gets its own document here.
Daily Challenges. dailyChallenges tracks completed challenges by date. This powers the streak calculation and daily engagement metrics.
User Notes. The notes subcollection stores user notes per lesson. Personal annotations that persist across sessions.
Course Document. Each course progress document contains summary data plus nested subcollections for detailed tracking.
Lesson Progress. Nested even deeper—lessonProgress tracks individual lessons. Viewed sections, completion status, last visit time. Granular tracking!
Activity Attempts. Every quiz answer, drag-drop completion, and code challenge is recorded in activityAttempts. Complete history of engagement!
Lesson Document. Each lesson document stores detailed progress—viewed sections array, timestamps, scroll position, and completion percentage.
Attempt Document. Individual attempt documents record each interaction—timestamp, answer given, whether it was correct, and score earned.

entity-relations-story.text: Partner Entity. The Partner is the core entity. Everything else—interactions, attachments, courses, analytics—relates back to a partner.
Interaction Entity. Partners have many interactions. Each call, meeting, or email creates a new interaction record linked to the partner.
Attachment Entity. Attachments can belong to partners or specific interactions. Proposals, contracts, presentations—all linked to context.
Partner Course. Partners offer courses to their members. Each course relationship tracks pricing, enrollment, and completion metrics.
Analytics Events. Partners generate analytics events. Every enrollment, completion, and interaction becomes a data point for insights.
Admin User. Admin users manage partners and create interactions. Every action is tracked with createdBy for accountability.

progress-flow-story.text: User Scrolls. The journey begins with a scroll. The user moves through lesson content, triggering the progress tracking system.
Observer Detects. IntersectionObserver fires when sections cross visibility thresholds. No expensive scroll listeners—just efficient threshold callbacks!
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker maintains the viewedSections set. Each visible section gets added, tracking exactly what's been seen.
Calculate Percentage. Progress percentage is calculated. Viewed sections divided by total sections equals completion. Simple math, powerful tracking!
DataService Saves. DataService receives the progress update and initiates the dual-write pattern. Two writes ensure dashboard optimization!
Subcollection Write. First write goes to the lessonProgress subcollection. Detailed data—viewed sections, timestamps, completion status.
Parent Field Write. Second write updates the parent courseProgress document. The lessons field gives dashboard a quick summary without deep queries!

dashboard-data-story.text: Stats Cards. The dashboard's stats cards show velocity, mastery, and streak. Each metric pulls from different data sources and calculations.
Velocity Calculation. Learning Velocity comes from lesson completion records. Lessons completed per week, scaled to a 0-100 score.
Mastery Calculation. Quiz Mastery averages scores from activityAttempts. Higher correct rates mean higher mastery percentages.
Streak Calculation. Streak counts consecutive active days. Data comes from dailyChallenges and user document's lastActive timestamp.
Lesson Progress Data. Velocity reads from lessonProgress collection. Completion timestamps let us calculate lessons per week.
Activity Attempts Data. Mastery reads from activityAttempts. Each attempt's score contributes to the average.
Daily Challenges Data. Streak calculation uses dailyChallenges. Each dated document proves that day's activity.
Course Grid. The course grid shows enrolled courses with progress bars. Data flows from courseProgress documents.
Progress Calculation. Course progress percentages come from the lessons summary field. Quick reads, no deep queries needed.
Course Progress Data. The courseProgress collection provides course-level summaries. Each enrolled course has a document here.
Activity Feed. The activity feed shows recent actions. Recent quiz attempts, lesson completions, and achievements.
Profile Bar. The profile bar displays user name and photo. Simple read from the user document.
User Document. The user document provides profile data and lastActive timestamp. Foundation for personalization!

auth-architecture-story.text: The User. Every authentication journey starts with a user. They want to log in, access their progress, and continue learning.
AuthService. AuthService is the gateway. It provides clean methods for login, registration, and logout—wrapping Firebase's complexity.
Firebase Auth. Firebase Auth handles the heavy lifting. Token management, session persistence, OAuth flows—all handled securely by Google's infrastructure.
Google OAuth. For Google login, Firebase connects to Google's OAuth servers. One-click authentication using existing Google accounts!
Auth State. Auth State manages the user's session. It tracks whether someone is logged in, handles token refresh, and persists across browser tabs.
User Document. After authentication, we sync with Firestore. The user document stores profile info, roles, and organization memberships.

registration-flow-story.text: Registration Form. New users start with the registration form. They enter email, password, and display name—the essentials for creating an account.
Input Validation. Before hitting Firebase, we validate locally. Is the email formatted correctly? Is the password strong enough? Catch errors early!
Create Auth Account. createUserWithEmailAndPassword creates the Firebase Auth account. A unique UID is generated—the user's permanent identifier.
Update Profile. updateProfile sets the display name on the Firebase Auth record. This makes the name available immediately across all Firebase services.
Create User Document. With auth complete, we create the Firestore user document. Profile info, default role, creation timestamp—everything initialized!
Auth State Change. onAuthStateChanged fires across the app. Every component listening knows a new user just logged in. Time to update the UI!
Welcome to Dashboard. Registration complete! Auth state changes, listeners fire, and the user lands on their brand new dashboard. Learning begins!

role-hierarchy-story.text: Admin Role. At the top sits the admin role. Full platform access—all courses, user management, organization controls. The keys to the kingdom!
Enterprise Role. Enterprise users belong to organizations. They inherit all standard user permissions PLUS access to partner courses for their org.
Standard User. Standard users form the base. Public courses, personal dashboard, progress tracking. Everything needed for self-paced learning!
Public Course Access. Standard users can access all public courses. Apprentice, Junior, Senior—the full curriculum is open to everyone who registers.
Dashboard Access. Every user gets a personal dashboard. Track progress, see achievements, pick up where you left off. Your learning command center!
Partner Course Access. Enterprise users unlock partner courses. Organization-specific content tailored to their learning path and requirements.
Admin Tools. Admins get special tools. User management, content administration, analytics dashboards—the backend of the platform.
All Courses Access. Admins can access every course—public, partner, or otherwise. Nothing is hidden from the platform administrators.
Apprentice Course. Apprentice is the first public course. Git fundamentals, command line basics—the foundation for every developer's journey.
Junior Course. Junior level builds on Apprentice. More advanced topics, collaborative workflows, professional practices.
Endless Opportunities. Endless Opportunities is a partner-exclusive course. Custom content for a specific organization's learning needs.
Admin Dashboard. The admin dashboard is locked tight. User lists, organization management, system metrics—for platform administrators only.

access-check-story.text: Access Request. A user wants a protected resource. The RBAC system activates—a series of checks to determine if access is allowed.
Authentication Check. First gate: Is there a valid user session? No login means no access. Redirect to the login page immediately.
Redirect to Login. No authentication found! The user is redirected to the login page. Come back after you've signed in.
Get Permissions. User is authenticated! Now we load their RBAC data—role, organizations, granted permissions. What can they do?
Admin Bypass. Admins get VIP treatment—they bypass all other checks! If role equals admin, access is granted immediately.
Admin Allowed. Admin role confirmed! Access granted without further checks. Admins can go anywhere on the platform.
Course Requirements. Not an admin? Check what the course requires. Is it public? Does it need organization membership? Let's find out.
Public Course Check. Is this a public course? If yes, any authenticated user can access. No further checks needed!
Public Allowed. It's a public course! Any logged-in user can access. Welcome to the free content!
Organization Check. For partner courses, verify organization membership. The user's organizations array must include the required org.
Not in Organization. User isn't in the required organization. Access denied! Contact your admin to get added to the org.
Course Access Check. User is in the organization! But does their membership include this specific course? One more check to go.
Access Granted!. All checks passed! The user has the right role, belongs to the right org, and has course access. Welcome in!
Access Denied. Organization membership confirmed, but this course isn't included. Ask your organization admin for access.

route-guard-story.text: Page Load. A user navigates to a page. RouteGuard intercepts before any content renders. Time for security checks!
Protected Check. First, isProtectedPage checks the URL. Marketing pages pass through. Dashboard and lessons require authentication.
Public Page. This is a public page! No authentication required. Content loads immediately for everyone.
Show Loading. For protected pages, we show a loading screen. Content stays hidden until auth state is confirmed. No flash of forbidden content!
Wait for Auth. waitForAuthState returns a promise. It resolves when Firebase Auth confirms the user's session status. Patient waiting!
Check User. Auth state resolved! Now we check—is there a current user? Signed in or anonymous? This decides the next step.
Redirect to Login. No user signed in! Redirect to the login page with a return URL. After login, they'll come right back here.
RBAC Verification. With authentication confirmed, RBAC kicks in. Does this user have permission for this specific page and course?
Show Content. All checks passed! The loading screen fades, content appears, and the user can interact. RouteGuard's job is done!
Access Denied. RBAC check failed! User doesn't have permission. Show an error message and offer navigation alternatives.

org-access-story.text: Alice: Standard User. Meet Alice, a standard user. She can access all public courses—Apprentice and beyond. No organization membership.
Bob: Enterprise User. Bob is an enterprise user with Endless Opportunities. He gets public courses PLUS the exclusive EO Bootcamp content!
Carol: Partner X Member. Carol is also enterprise, but with Partner X. Different organization means different exclusive content.
Admin: Full Access. The admin can access everything! Public courses, all partner courses, every piece of content. Ultimate override authority!
Endless Opportunities. Bob's user document lists Endless Opportunities in his organizations array. This unlocks EO-specific content.
Partner X Organization. Carol belongs to Partner X. Her organization membership grants access to Partner X's exclusive courses.
Public Courses. The Apprentice course is public—everyone with an account can access it. Alice, Bob, Carol, and Admin all qualify.
EO Bootcamp. The EO Bootcamp is linked to Endless Opportunities. Only Bob and Admin can access—Carol and Alice cannot.
Partner X Course. Partner X's course is exclusive to their members. Carol and Admin can access it—Bob and Alice cannot.

tracking-overview-story.text: User Scrolls. Progress tracking starts with user actions. Scrolling through content triggers the ProgressTracker to monitor visibility.
Quiz Answer. When users answer quiz questions, that interaction is captured. Every answer matters for tracking engagement!
Drag & Drop. Completing drag and drop activities signals active learning. These hands-on interactions are especially valuable to track.
ProgressTracker. ProgressTracker watches scrolling behavior. It uses IntersectionObserver to detect which sections users have viewed.
ActivityTracker. ActivityTracker handles interactive elements. Quiz answers, drag completions, code challenges—every interaction is captured.
DataService. Both trackers feed into DataService. Progress and activity data flows to Firestore for permanent storage.
Lesson Progress. The lessonProgress subcollection stores completion data. Which sections viewed, percentage complete, completion timestamp.
Activity Attempts. Every quiz attempt lands in activityAttempts. Score, timestamp, correct answers—full history preserved!
LocalStorage Cache. LocalStorage provides offline backup. If the network fails, attempts queue locally until connection returns.
Progress Bar. The progress bar updates in real-time as users scroll. Visual feedback shows exactly how much content remains.
Quiz Feedback. Instant feedback appears after quiz submission. Correct answers highlighted, explanations shown. Learn from every attempt!
Completion Toast. Hit 90 percent? A celebration toast appears! Positive reinforcement keeps learners motivated to continue.

section-discovery-story.text: Page Load. The lesson page loads. ProgressTracker needs to know what sections exist before it can track them.
Tracker Initializes. ProgressTracker.init kicks off the discovery process. Time to find all trackable sections on the page!
Discover Sections. discoverSections scans the DOM for trackable content. It looks for specific attributes marking important sections.
Query Selectors. querySelectorAll finds all elements with data-section attributes. These are our trackable content sections.
Sections Array. All discovered sections are stored in an array. This becomes the denominator for progress calculation.
Observer Setup. Finally, IntersectionObserver is created and attached to each section. Scroll tracking is now active!

scroll-observation-story.text: User Scrolls. The user scrolls through lesson content. Every movement could reveal new sections and advance progress.
Observer Monitors. IntersectionObserver watches visibility changes. Unlike scroll events, it only fires when thresholds are crossed. Efficient!
Callback Triggered. When a section crosses the visibility threshold, the callback fires. Time to check if this section should be marked!
Visibility Check. When a section crosses 50 percent visibility, isIntersecting returns true. The section has been meaningfully viewed.
Mark as Viewed. The section ID is added to the viewedSections Set. Sets prevent duplicates—view a section twice, it still only counts once.
Calculate Progress. Progress percentage is recalculated. Viewed sections divided by total sections times 100. Simple but powerful!
Debounced Save. Progress is saved with debouncing—multiple rapid views trigger just one Firestore write. Network efficiency!

activity-types-story.text: ActivityTracker Hub. ActivityTracker is the hub for all interactive elements. It discovers activities on page load and tracks their completion.
Quiz Activities. Quizzes test understanding with multiple choice questions. Select an answer, submit, get instant feedback!
Drag & Drop. Drag and drop activities teach through interaction. Match items to targets, sort sequences, build connections.
Code Challenges. Code challenges test real programming skills. Write or complete code, run it, check the output!
Interactive Demos. Interactive demos let users explore concepts hands-on. Click, experiment, discover—learning by doing!
data-answer Attribute. Quizzes use data-answer to define correct answers. Hidden from users but accessible to JavaScript for validation.
data-target Attribute. Drag activities use data-target to map items to zones. Drop in the right zone to complete the activity.
data-solution Attribute. Code challenges have data-solution for expected output. User code is compared against this for validation.
data-complete Attribute. Demos use data-complete to define completion criteria. Reach the goal state and the activity is done!
Firestore Storage. Every attempt is saved to Firestore's activityAttempts subcollection. Complete history of engagement!
LocalStorage Backup. LocalStorage provides offline resilience. If Firestore is unreachable, attempts queue locally until sync.

offline-flow-story.text: Activity Attempt. A user completes an activity. But wait—what if they're offline? The internet isn't always reliable!
Connection Check. navigator.onLine tells us the connection status. Online? Save directly. Offline? Time for the queue!
Save to Firestore. Online path: the attempt goes directly to Firestore. Quick, reliable, permanent storage in the cloud.
Queue for Later. Offline path: attempts go into a queue. The activity is stored locally, waiting for reconnection.
LocalStorage Backup. The queue persists in LocalStorage. Even if the browser closes, queued attempts survive.
Connection Restored. The online event fires when connection returns. Time to sync those queued attempts!
Sync Process. syncQueuedAttempts processes the queue. Each pending attempt is saved to Firestore in order.
Clear Queue. After successful sync, the queue is cleared. No duplicates, no data loss. Offline support complete!

analytics-metrics-story.text: Lesson Progress Data. Analytics starts with raw data from Firestore. Lesson completion records tell us what content users have consumed.
Activity Attempts Data. Quiz attempts and scores provide mastery signals. How well are users understanding the material?
Daily Challenges. Daily challenge completions show consistency. Regular engagement builds lasting learning habits.
User Profile Data. The user document stores streak information. Current streak, longest streak, last active date.
Calculate Velocity. calcVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed per week, multiplied by 20, gives a 0-100 velocity score.
Calculate Mastery. calcMastery averages quiz performance. Correct answers divided by total attempts—expressed as a percentage.
Calculate Streak. calcStreak counts consecutive days with activity. Miss a day? Streak resets. Consistency is rewarded!
Learning Velocity. Learning Velocity is displayed as a 0-100 score. Higher means faster progression through content.
Quiz Mastery. Quiz Mastery shows as a percentage. 80 percent or higher means strong understanding!
Active Streak. Active Streak displays as a day count. Keep it going—consistency builds knowledge!
Calculate Cognitive. The Cognitive Score combines all metrics with weights: 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion.
Cognitive Score. The final Cognitive Score is a holistic measure of learning progress. One number to track overall growth!

completion-flow-story.text: 90% Threshold. Progress hits 90 percent! This is the magic threshold—the lesson is essentially complete when this milestone is reached.
Already Complete?. Before celebrating, we check if the lesson was already marked complete. No duplicate celebrations!
Mark Complete. markLessonComplete sets the completion flag. This is a one-time operation per lesson.
Event Dispatch. A lessonComplete event broadcasts to the app. Other components can react—update UI, show notifications, unlock content.
Save to Firestore. Completion is persisted to Firestore. The lessonProgress document updates with completedAt timestamp.
Celebration Toast!. A toast notification appears celebrating the achievement. Visual feedback motivates continued learning!
Update Course Progress. The course document increments completedLessons. Course-level progress reflects individual lesson completions.
Streak Updated. Finally, the user's streak is refreshed. Completing a lesson counts as daily activity. Keep that streak alive!

css-mapping-story.text: Marketing Styles. marketing.css handles landing pages and catalog pages. Hero sections, feature grids, testimonials—all the public-facing flair!
Landing Page. The landing page is the first impression. Hero section, value props, call-to-action—all styled by marketing.css.
Course Catalog. The catalog showcases all available courses. Card grids, filters, course previews—marketing.css makes it shine.
Auth Styles. auth.css styles login and registration forms. Centered cards, input fields, validation messages—clean and focused.
Login Page. The login page is minimal and focused. Email, password, submit—no distractions, just authentication.
Register Page. Registration adds display name to the form. Same clean styling, slightly longer form, welcoming new users.
Dashboard Styles. dashboard.css creates the user hub layout. Sidebar navigation, stats cards, course grids, activity feeds.
User Dashboard. The dashboard is the user's home base. Progress overview, enrolled courses, recent activity—all in one place.
Lesson Styles. lesson.css is the richest file. Content sections, code blocks, quizzes, drag-drop zones, progress indicators!
Lesson Pages. Every lesson page uses these styles. Interactive content, readable typography, engaging activities.
Blog Styles. blog.css handles article formatting. Long-form content, images, code snippets—optimized for reading.
Blog Pages. Blog articles share knowledge beyond courses. Same quality typography and styling, different content focus.

design-tokens-story.text: CSS Custom Properties. All design tokens live in the root selector as CSS custom properties. One source of truth for the entire design system!
Color Palette. Colors define the dark theme aesthetic. Primary backgrounds, accent colors, success and error states. Carefully chosen for contrast!
Primary Background. bg-primary is the darkest at hash 0a0a0f. The main canvas color, providing maximum contrast for content.
Secondary Background. bg-secondary is slightly lighter at hash 12121a. Used for cards and elevated surfaces to create depth.
Primary Accent. accent-primary is our signature purple. Links, buttons, interactive elements—it draws the eye to action!
Success Color. accent-success is a vibrant green. Correct answers, completed tasks, positive feedback—celebration in color!
Spacing Scale. Spacing tokens create consistent rhythm. Small, medium, large—predictable gaps throughout the UI.
Small Spacing. spacing-sm is half a rem. Tight gaps between related elements, compact but not cramped.
Medium Spacing. spacing-md is one rem. The default gap, comfortable separation between most elements.
Large Spacing. spacing-lg is one and a half rem. Section separators, content breaks, breathing room!
Typography. Two font families define our look. Inter for body text—clean and readable. Space Grotesk for headings—bold and modern!
Body Font. Inter is our body font. Excellent legibility at all sizes, perfect for long-form content reading.
Display Font. Space Grotesk is for headings. Bold geometric shapes make titles pop and grab attention.
Effects. Shadows and transitions bring the UI to life. Subtle effects, big impact on polish!
Medium Shadow. shadow-md adds depth to cards and modals. Soft edges, subtle elevation—professional polish.
Standard Transition. transition-medium is 300ms ease. Smooth state changes, not too fast, not too slow. Just right!

animation-flow-story.text: Page Load Trigger. Page load triggers entrance animations. Content fades in, elements stagger into view. First impressions matter!
Scroll Trigger. Scrolling triggers reveal animations. As users explore, content animates into the viewport. Progressive discovery!
Hover Trigger. Mouse hover triggers interactive feedback. Buttons grow, cards lift, colors shift. Immediate response to user intent!
Click Trigger. Clicks trigger action animations. Ripples, expansions, state transitions. Confirming user actions visually!
IntersectionObserver. IntersectionObserver efficiently detects visibility. No scroll event spam—just precise threshold crossings.
Anime.js Engine. Anime.js handles complex animations. Staggered reveals, elastic easing, timeline sequences—smooth and performant!
CSS Transitions. Simple interactions use CSS transitions. Hover effects, focus states, color changes—no JavaScript needed!
Fade In Effect. The signature fade-in: opacity zero to one, translateY 20 to zero. Content rises into view. Elegant!
Stagger Effect. Stagger delays each element slightly. Lists and grids cascade into view—dynamic and engaging!
Slide Effect. Slide animations move elements horizontally or vertically. Drawers open, panels expand, content shifts!
Scale Effect. Scale transforms resize elements. Buttons grow on hover, cards enlarge on focus. Subtle emphasis!
Color Change. Color transitions shift hues smoothly. Hover states, active states, focus states—all visually distinct.

component-hierarchy-story.text: Card Component. Cards are our primary container pattern. A dark background with border, holding header, content, and footer sections.
Card Header. Card headers contain titles and icons. Consistent padding, bold typography—immediately scannable.
Card Content. Card content is flexible. Lists, paragraphs, charts, forms—any content fits within the card structure.
Card Footer. Card footers hold actions. Buttons, links, timestamps—everything that lets users take next steps.
Card Hover State. On hover, cards lift slightly and borders brighten. Subtle feedback that says 'this is interactive!'
Button Base. Buttons have a base class with shared styles. Padding, border-radius, font—consistent across variants.
Primary Button. Primary buttons demand attention. Solid accent background, high contrast text—the main call to action.
Secondary Button. Secondary buttons are subtle. Outlined style, lower visual weight—for alternative actions.
Progress Bar Container. Progress bars show completion visually. A container track with a fill element inside.
Progress Fill. The fill element shows actual progress. Width percentage equals progress percentage—simple and clear!

layout-patterns-story.text: Dashboard Layout. Dashboard uses a sidebar plus main content pattern. Fixed navigation on the left, scrollable content on the right.
Sidebar Navigation. The sidebar provides persistent navigation. 240 pixels wide, fixed position—always accessible!
Main Content Area. Main content fills the remaining space with flex-grow. Scrollable, responsive, the star of the show!
Dashboard Page. The dashboard page uses this layout. User's home base with sidebar navigation always available.
Lesson Layout. Lesson pages have three columns: fixed header, scrollable content center, progress nav on the right.
Fixed Header. A 60-pixel header stays at the top. Course title, breadcrumb, quick actions—context always visible.
Progress Navigation. Right sidebar tracks scroll position. Jump to sections, see progress at a glance, navigate efficiently!
Lesson Pages. All lesson pages share this layout. Consistent learning experience across all courses.
Marketing Layout. Marketing pages use full-width sections. No sidebar, no constraints—bold visual storytelling!
Hero Section. The hero section is the first impression. Full-width, bold headline, compelling CTA—capture attention!
Card Grid. Auto-fill grids showcase features or courses. Responsive columns, consistent cards, easy scanning.
Landing Page. The landing page showcases the platform. Hero, features, testimonials—scroll through the story!
Auth Layout. Auth pages center a single form card. Maximum focus on the task—sign in or register.
Centered Form Card. A max-width form card centers vertically and horizontally. Clean, focused, distraction-free!
Auth Pages. Login and register share this layout. Consistent authentication experience.

quiz-structure-story.text: Quiz Container. Every quiz starts with a container. The data-answer attribute holds the correct answer—hidden from the UI but accessible to JavaScript.
Question Text. The question is displayed prominently. Clear typography, adequate spacing—the user knows exactly what to answer.
Options Container. Options are grouped in a container. Vertical list or grid, depending on content length.
Individual Option. Each option has a data-value attribute. Click to select—visual feedback confirms the choice.
Submit Button. The submit button triggers validation. Disabled until a selection is made, then ready for action!
Feedback Area. The feedback area reveals after submission. Correct answer, explanation, encouragement—learning moment!
Selected State. Clicking an option adds the selected class. Border highlight, background change—clear visual selection!
Correct State. After submission, the correct answer gets the correct class. Green border, checkmark—celebration!
Incorrect State. Wrong selections get the incorrect class. Red border, x-mark—but with helpful explanation below!

breakpoints-story.text: Mobile First. Below 768 pixels is mobile territory. Single column layouts, hidden sidebars, stacked navigation. Touch-friendly targets!
Single Column. On mobile, content stacks vertically. No side-by-side layouts—everything flows top to bottom for easy scrolling.
Hidden Sidebar. Sidebars collapse to hamburger menus on mobile. Screen space is precious—content comes first!
Tablet Range. 768 to 1024 pixels is tablet territory. More space allows for some side-by-side layouts.
Two Columns. Two-column grids appear on tablets. Course cards side by side, better use of horizontal space.
Desktop Layout. 1024 to 1280 pixels is desktop range. Full layouts with visible sidebars, multi-column grids, expanded navigation.
Full Layout. Desktop shows the complete layout. Sidebar visible, three-column lessons, all features accessible.
Large Screens. Above 1280 pixels, we add constraints. Content doesn't stretch infinitely—readable line lengths are maintained.
Max Width Container. Max-width containers center content on large screens. 1200 pixel limit keeps text readable and layouts balanced.

color-contrast-story.text: Primary Background. bg-primary is the darkest background at hash 0a0a0f. Nearly black, it provides maximum contrast for text.
Secondary Background. bg-secondary at hash 12121a is slightly elevated. Used for cards and containers to create depth.
Card Background. bg-card at hash 16162a is even lighter. Cards pop against the page background. Visual hierarchy through shade!
Primary Text. text-primary is light gray at hash e8e8f0. Against bg-primary, it achieves 15.2:1 contrast—well above WCAG requirements!
Secondary Text. text-secondary at hash a8a8b8 is slightly dimmer. 8.5:1 contrast for less prominent text—still highly readable.
Muted Text. text-muted at hash 6a6a80 is the lightest text. 4.6:1 contrast—for hints, placeholders, de-emphasized content.
Primary Accent. accent-primary purple achieves 6.8:1 contrast on card backgrounds. Links and interactive elements stand out!
Success Green. accent-success at hash 66bb6a achieves 8.1:1 contrast. Perfect for positive feedback without being harsh.
Error Red. accent-error red achieves 5.2:1 contrast. Clear error indication while remaining readable on dark backgrounds.

feature-overview-story.text: Partnership Portal. Welcome to the Partnership Portal! This admin-only system helps manage relationships with educational organizations, churches, foundations, and businesses.
Partner List. The partner list shows all organizations at a glance. Filter by type, status, or search by name. Your partnership CRM!
Partner Details. Each partner has a detailed view. Contact info, interaction history, attached documents, courses offered, and analytics.
Add Partner. Adding new partners is easy. Fill out the form, select type and status, and the relationship tracking begins!
Interactions. Every touchpoint is recorded. Calls, meetings, emails, demos—complete history of the relationship journey.
Attachments. Attach files to any partner. Proposals, contracts, presentations—all organized and easily accessible.
Analytics Dashboard. Time-series analytics track partnership health. Enrollments, revenue, engagement—data-driven decisions!
Schools. School partners include K-12 districts, individual schools, and after-school programs. Education at scale!
Churches. Churches and religious organizations partner to serve their communities with tech education opportunities.
Foundations. Non-profit foundations and community organizations bring funding and mission alignment to partnerships.
Businesses. Corporate partners invest in workforce development. Training pipelines for future employees!
Community Orgs. Community organizations provide grassroots connections. Local impact, trusted relationships!
Free Courses. Partners can offer our four free evergreen courses. Apprentice through Senior—foundational curriculum!
Custom Courses. Custom curriculum tailored to partner needs. Industry-specific content, branded experiences!
Live Cohorts. Live cohort teaching with instructors. Scheduled classes, real-time interaction, guided learning!
Digital Access. Self-paced digital access for partner members. Interactive lessons available anytime, anywhere!

data-model-story.text: Firestore Root. Partnership data lives in Firestore with a hierarchical structure. Top-level partners collection with nested subcollections.
Partners Collection. The partners collection holds all partner documents. Each organization gets one document identified by a unique ID.
Partner Document. Each partner document contains organization details, contact info, status, and metrics. But wait—there's more in subcollections!
Interactions Subcollection. Every touchpoint is recorded in the interactions subcollection. Calls, meetings, emails, demos—complete relationship history.
Attachments Subcollection. Files and documents live in attachments. Proposals, contracts, presentations—linked to partners or specific interactions.
Courses Subcollection. Partner course offerings are tracked in courses. Which courses they offer, enrollment counts, completion rates.
Analytics Subcollection. Time-series analytics in the analytics subcollection. Student enrollments, cohort completions, revenue—all trackable over time.
Interaction Document. Each interaction document has type, notes, outcome, next steps. A complete record of every touchpoint!
Attachment Document. Attachment documents store metadata and Storage URLs. File name, type, upload date, who uploaded it.
Course Document. Course documents link partners to curriculum. Course ID, start date, pricing, enrollment cap, current enrollment.
Analytics Event. Analytics events capture moments. Student enrolled, cohort started, revenue recorded—timestamped for trending!

status-flow-story.text: Initial Contact. Every partnership begins with initial contact. A lead comes in, we add them to the system, and the journey begins!
Prospect Status. New partners start as prospects. Discovery calls, evaluating fit, understanding their needs. Building the relationship foundation.
Active Partnership. Agreement signed! Active partners have courses running, students enrolled, cohorts in progress. The partnership is live!
Paused Status. Sometimes partnerships pause. Between cohorts, budget reviews, organizational changes. Not ended—just on hold.
Churned Status. Churned means the partnership ended. Lost opportunity or completed engagement. But re-engagement is always possible!

interaction-flow-story.text: Admin User. An admin just had a call with a partner. Time to record it! Every touchpoint deserves documentation.
Interaction Form. The form captures details—type, title, description, outcome, next steps. Structured data for consistent tracking.
PartnerService. createInteraction in PartnerService handles the save. It updates multiple documents in a coordinated operation.
Save Interaction. The interaction document is created in the subcollection. Timestamp, admin ID, all details preserved.
Update Partner. The parent partner document updates too—lastInteractionAt, totalInteractions count. Quick dashboard metrics!
Record Analytics. An analytics event is also recorded. This interaction becomes a data point in the partnership timeline!
Update Timeline. The UI timeline updates to show the new interaction. Visual history of all touchpoints with this partner!

service-layer-story.text: Partner List UI. The partner list page shows all partners. Filter, search, sort—find any partner quickly!
Partner Detail UI. The detail page shows everything about one partner. Profile, interactions, attachments, courses, analytics.
Partner Forms UI. Forms for adding and editing partners. Clean interfaces for data entry and updates.
Timeline UI. The interaction timeline shows chronological history. Every touchpoint visualized on a scrollable timeline!
Analytics Dashboard UI. Charts and metrics for partnership health. Trends, comparisons, insights—data visualization!
getPartners(). getPartners fetches the partner list. Supports filters for type, status, search term.
getPartner(). getPartner fetches one partner by ID. Includes subcollection data for the full picture.
createPartner(). createPartner adds a new partner document. Initializes all fields, sets creation timestamp.
createInteraction(). createInteraction records a new touchpoint. Updates partner doc and creates analytics event too.
uploadAttachment(). uploadAttachment handles file uploads. Saves to Storage, creates metadata doc in Firestore.
getAnalytics(). getAnalytics fetches time-series events. Supports date ranges and aggregation options.
Firestore Database. All data flows to and from Firestore. The central database for partnership information.
Firebase Storage. File uploads go to Firebase Storage. The URL is then saved in Firestore with metadata. Best of both!

analytics-flow-story.text: Student Enrolled. Student enrollment triggers an analytics event. A new learner joins through this partner!
Cohort Started. Cohort start is a major milestone. A new group begins their learning journey with this partner!
Cohort Completed. Cohort completion celebrates success. Students graduated, skills gained, outcomes achieved!
Interaction Logged. Every interaction with the partner is an event. Relationship health requires consistent touchpoints!
Revenue Recorded. Revenue events track financial health. Payments, sponsorships, donations—all recorded.
Store Events. All events are stored with timestamps in the analytics subcollection. Time-series data ready for analysis!
Aggregate Data. Events are grouped by date, type, and partner. Daily, weekly, monthly rollups enable trend analysis.
Calculate Trends. Calculations reveal insights. Growth rates, completion percentages, revenue trends—metrics that drive decisions.
Activity Line Chart. Line charts show trends over time. Activity spikes, seasonal patterns, growth trajectories!
Status Bar Chart. Bar charts compare categories. Partners by status, revenue by type, enrollments by month!
Type Pie Chart. Pie charts show composition. Partner types, course distribution, revenue breakdown—parts of a whole!
Top Partners Table. Tables rank partners by metrics. Top enrollers, highest revenue, most engaged—leaderboard style!

page-structure-story.text: Admin Section. Partnership pages live under the admin section. Only users with admin role can access any of these features.
Partnerships Folder. The partnerships folder contains all portal pages. A logical grouping within the admin area.
Partner List Page. index.html is the main dashboard. All partners listed with filters, search, and quick actions.
Partner Detail Page. partner.html shows individual partner details. Timeline, attachments, courses, metrics—the complete picture.
Add Partner Page. add.html is the partner creation form. Enter all details to start tracking a new partnership!
Analytics Page. analytics.html provides the big picture. Aggregate metrics across all partnerships, trends, and insights.

service-story.text: Foundation: Firebase Config. Everything starts here. FirebaseApp initializes the Firebase SDK, establishing connections to Authentication and Firestore. This is loaded first on every page.
Authentication Layer. AuthService wraps Firebase Auth, managing user sessions, login flows, and auth state changes. It depends on FirebaseApp for the auth instance.
Data Access Layer. DataService handles all Firestore CRUD operations. It needs FirebaseApp for database access AND AuthService to scope queries to the current user.
Role-Based Access Control. RBACService checks user roles and permissions. It queries AuthService to get the current user, then checks their role against required permissions.
Progress Tracking. ProgressTracker uses IntersectionObserver to detect which content users have viewed. It saves progress via DataService and identifies users via AuthService.
Activity Completion. ActivityTracker records quiz answers and exercise completions. Like ProgressTracker, it writes to Firestore via DataService for authenticated users.
Route Protection. RouteGuard runs on page load to check if users can access the current page. It verifies authentication status AND role requirements before showing content.
Lesson Orchestration. Finally, LessonIntegration ties it all together on lesson pages. It coordinates ProgressTracker and ActivityTracker to create a seamless learning experience.

dataflow-story.text: User Initiates Action. It all starts with a user interaction—clicking a Complete Quiz button, scrolling past a section, or submitting a form. The browser captures this event.
Event Handler Catches It. The DOM event handler fires. This is JavaScript code in the page that responds to user actions and decides what to do next.
Service Method Called. The handler calls a service method like ProgressTracker.markComplete or ActivityTracker.submitAnswer. Business logic lives in these services, not in UI code.
Authentication Verified. Before writing data, the service checks AuthService.getCurrentUser. If no user is logged in, the action may be queued or rejected.
Data Written to Firestore. The service calls Firestore to persist the data. This might be updating a progress document, saving quiz answers, or logging activity.
Realtime Listener Triggers. Firestores onSnapshot listeners detect the change instantly. Any component subscribed to this data gets notified automatically.
Local State Updates. The listener callback updates the local state. This keeps the UI in sync with the database.
UI Reflects the Change. Finally, the UI re-renders to show the new state. A progress bar fills, a checkmark appears, or a success toast shows. The cycle is complete!
